title: Stay safe on the roads this winter with our EXPERT tips
text:
Stay safe on the roads this winter with our EXPERT tips Stay safe on the roads this winter with our EXPERT tips WHEN the hour does change it is prime time for accidents on the UK’s wet and crowded roads. PUBLISHED: 16:51, Tue, Oct 20, 2015 | UPDATED: 16:59, Tue, Oct 20, 2015 GETTY Before driving in winter conditions, make sure all lights on the car are working 
The darker nights see more drivers commuting in the gloom, often in damp or frosty weather. 
GoCompare.com, the comparison site, said October is the second worst month for motor claims, with December the worst. 
Spokesman Matt Oliver said: “Accidents increase as more people use their cars in bad weather and visibility is bad due to low autumn sunshine.” Accidents increase as more people use their cars in bad weather and visibility is bad due to low autumn sunshine Matt Oliver, GoCompare.com 
AA Insurance managing director Janet Connor warned: “October is the wettest month of the year and falling leaves can cause greasy road surfaces. 
“Most drivers are aware of the greater risks but a few drive as if nothing’s changed. So collisions can be pretty serious, leading to claims for damage and injury.” 
Insurer RIAS said its data shows car accidents spike by around 10 per cent at this time. 
The Chartered Insurance Institute has published its top tips for safe winter motoring on its new website AskCiindy.com. GETTY Keep a pair of sunglasses in your car so that you can avoid being dazzled by the sun 
It suggests the following: Make sure all your headlights, indicators, brake lights and reverse lights are working. Don’t wait until it is fully dark before you put your lights on. Keep a pair of sunglasses in your car so that you can avoid being dazzled by the sun. Check your windscreen wipers are in good working order and the washer fluid is topped up. Allow extra time to de-mist your windows before you set off. Stock up on de-icer and get a scraper so you can clear ice and snow from your car. Check tyre pressures to ensure they are at the correct levels. Top up your water, oil and brake fluid levels to keep your engine running smoothly. Related articles
